name: g
description: Runs Git so you can execute repository commands. Example: `git status`. Pitfalls: Running outside a repo fails; cd into a repo first. Why: starting point for every Git task.

name: ga
description: Stages selected file changes for your next commit. Example: `git add src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: using `git add .` may stage binaries/build output; check `git status` and unstage with `git restore --staged <file>`. Why: make focused commits reviewers can understand.

name: gaa
description: Stages all changes, including deletions and new files. Example: `git add --all`. Pitfalls: can grab unwanted deletes or generated files; review with `git status` before commit. Why: fast when you truly want every change.

name: gapa
description: Lets you stage only specific change chunks interactively. Example: `git add --patch src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: picking wrong hunks creates mixed commits; verify with `git diff --cached`. Why: great for splitting big edits into clean commits.

name: gau
description: Stages selected file changes for your next commit. Example: `git add src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: using `git add .` may stage binaries/build output; check `git status` and unstage with `git restore --staged <file>`. Why: make focused commits reviewers can understand.

name: gav
description: Stages selected file changes for your next commit. Example: `git add src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: using `git add .` may stage binaries/build output; check `git status` and unstage with `git restore --staged <file>`. Why: make focused commits reviewers can understand.

name: gwip
command: git add -A; git rm $(git ls-files --deleted) 2> /dev/null; git commit --no-verify --no-gpg-sign -m "--wip-- [skip ci]"
description: Runs multiple Git commands in sequence as one shortcut. Example: `git add --all && git commit -m "WIP"`. Pitfalls: combined steps can hide mistakes; run `git status` before/after. Why: faster repetitive workflows.

name: gam
description: Applies email-style patch files as commits on your current branch. Example: `git am 0001-fix-login.patch`. Pitfalls: patch context can fail on old code; update base branch or resolve conflicts then continue. Why: useful when teams share patches by email/export.

name: gama
description: Applies email-style patch files as commits on your current branch. Example: `git am 0001-fix-login.patch`. Pitfalls: patch context can fail on old code; update base branch or resolve conflicts then continue. Why: useful when teams share patches by email/export.

name: gamc
description: Applies email-style patch files as commits on your current branch. Example: `git am 0001-fix-login.patch`. Pitfalls: patch context can fail on old code; update base branch or resolve conflicts then continue. Why: useful when teams share patches by email/export.

name: gamscp
description: Applies email-style patch files as commits on your current branch. Example: `git am 0001-fix-login.patch`. Pitfalls: patch context can fail on old code; update base branch or resolve conflicts then continue. Why: useful when teams share patches by email/export.

name: gams
description: Applies email-style patch files as commits on your current branch. Example: `git am 0001-fix-login.patch`. Pitfalls: patch context can fail on old code; update base branch or resolve conflicts then continue. Why: useful when teams share patches by email/export.

name: gap
description: Applies patch changes to files without creating a commit. Example: `git apply fix.patch`. Pitfalls: patch may fail on changed files; try `git apply --3way` or update your branch. Why: quick way to test external fixes before committing.

name: gapt
description: Applies patch changes to files without creating a commit. Example: `git apply fix.patch`. Pitfalls: patch may fail on changed files; try `git apply --3way` or update your branch. Why: quick way to test external fixes before committing.

name: gbs
description: Helps find the bug-introducing commit with binary search steps. Example: `git bisect start`. Pitfalls: marking commits incorrectly gives wrong results; run a reliable test each step. Why: find regressions much faster than manual checking.

name: gbsb
description: Helps find the bug-introducing commit with binary search steps. Example: `git bisect start`. Pitfalls: marking commits incorrectly gives wrong results; run a reliable test each step. Why: find regressions much faster than manual checking.

name: gbsg
description: Helps find the bug-introducing commit with binary search steps. Example: `git bisect start`. Pitfalls: marking commits incorrectly gives wrong results; run a reliable test each step. Why: find regressions much faster than manual checking.

name: gbsr
description: Helps find the bug-introducing commit with binary search steps. Example: `git bisect start`. Pitfalls: marking commits incorrectly gives wrong results; run a reliable test each step. Why: find regressions much faster than manual checking.

name: gbss
description: Helps find the bug-introducing commit with binary search steps. Example: `git bisect start`. Pitfalls: marking commits incorrectly gives wrong results; run a reliable test each step. Why: find regressions much faster than manual checking.

name: gbl
description: Shows who last changed each line in a file and when. Example: `git blame src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: blame lacks full context; open related commits before deciding ownership. Why: great for tracing code history quickly.

name: gb
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gbda
command: git branch --no-color --merged | command grep -vE "^([+*]|\s*($(git_main_branch)|$(git_develop_branch))\s*$)" | command xargs git branch -d 2>/dev/null
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gbnm
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gbD
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gco
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gcor
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gcb
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gcd
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gch
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gcr
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gcm
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gcp
description: Copies a specific commit from another branch onto your current branch. Example: `git cherry-pick a1b2c3d`. Pitfalls: picking commits out of order can break code; include dependency commits too. Why: move targeted fixes without full branch merges.

name: gcpa
description: Copies a specific commit from another branch onto your current branch. Example: `git cherry-pick a1b2c3d`. Pitfalls: picking commits out of order can break code; include dependency commits too. Why: move targeted fixes without full branch merges.

name: gcpc
description: Copies a specific commit from another branch onto your current branch. Example: `git cherry-pick a1b2c3d`. Pitfalls: picking commits out of order can break code; include dependency commits too. Why: move targeted fixes without full branch merges.

name: gclean
description: Deletes untracked files/folders (interactive here). Example: `git clean -id`. Pitfalls: can remove important local files; preview with `git clean -nd` first. Why: quick workspace cleanup.

name: gcl
description: Creates a local copy of a remote repository. Example: `git clone --recurse-submodules https://github.com/org/repo.git`. Pitfalls: missing submodules can break builds; use `--recurse-submodules` then update recursively. Why: first step to start contributing.

name: gcam
description: Creates a commit from staged changes with a message. Example: `git commit -m "Add login feature"`. Pitfalls: forgetting `git add` commits nothing; apostrophes can break shell quoting, so use double quotes or editor mode. Why: records progress in clear checkpoints.

name: gcas
description: Runs this alias command for a common Git workflow task. Example: `git commit -a -s`. Pitfalls: aliases can hide details; inspect expanded command if behavior surprises you. Why: saves typing while keeping habits consistent.

name: gcasm
description: Creates a commit from staged changes with a message. Example: `git commit -m "Add login feature"`. Pitfalls: forgetting `git add` commits nothing; apostrophes can break shell quoting, so use double quotes or editor mode. Why: records progress in clear checkpoints.

name: gcmsg
description: Creates a commit from staged changes with a message. Example: `git commit -m "Add login feature"`. Pitfalls: forgetting `git add` commits nothing; apostrophes can break shell quoting, so use double quotes or editor mode. Why: records progress in clear checkpoints.

name: gcs
description: Runs this alias command for a common Git workflow task. Example: `git commit -S`. Pitfalls: aliases can hide details; inspect expanded command if behavior surprises you. Why: saves typing while keeping habits consistent.

name: gcsm
description: Creates a commit from staged changes with a message. Example: `git commit -m "Add login feature"`. Pitfalls: forgetting `git add` commits nothing; apostrophes can break shell quoting, so use double quotes or editor mode. Why: records progress in clear checkpoints.

name: gcss
description: Runs this alias command for a common Git workflow task. Example: `git commit -S -s`. Pitfalls: aliases can hide details; inspect expanded command if behavior surprises you. Why: saves typing while keeping habits consistent.

name: gcssm
description: Creates a commit from staged changes with a message. Example: `git commit -m "Add login feature"`. Pitfalls: forgetting `git add` commits nothing; apostrophes can break shell quoting, so use double quotes or editor mode. Why: records progress in clear checkpoints.

name: gc
description: Runs this alias command for a common Git workflow task. Example: `git commit -v`. Pitfalls: aliases can hide details; inspect expanded command if behavior surprises you. Why: saves typing while keeping habits consistent.

name: gc!
description: Rewrites the most recent commit with staged updates. Example: `git commit --amend --no-edit`. Pitfalls: amending already-pushed commits rewrites shared history; create a new commit instead. Why: quickly fix last-commit mistakes before push.

name: gcn
description: Runs this alias command for a common Git workflow task. Example: `git commit -v --no-edit`. Pitfalls: aliases can hide details; inspect expanded command if behavior surprises you. Why: saves typing while keeping habits consistent.

name: gcn!
description: Rewrites the most recent commit with staged updates. Example: `git commit --amend --no-edit`. Pitfalls: amending already-pushed commits rewrites shared history; create a new commit instead. Why: quickly fix last-commit mistakes before push.

name: gca
description: Runs this alias command for a common Git workflow task. Example: `git commit -v -a`. Pitfalls: aliases can hide details; inspect expanded command if behavior surprises you. Why: saves typing while keeping habits consistent.

name: gca!
description: Rewrites the most recent commit with staged updates. Example: `git commit --amend --no-edit`. Pitfalls: amending already-pushed commits rewrites shared history; create a new commit instead. Why: quickly fix last-commit mistakes before push.

name: gcan!

name: gcans!
description: Rewrites the most recent commit with staged updates. Example: `git commit --amend --no-edit`. Pitfalls: amending already-pushed commits rewrites shared history; create a new commit instead. Why: quickly fix last-commit mistakes before push.

name: gcf
description: Displays Git configuration values and where they come from. Example: `git config --list --show-origin`. Pitfalls: conflicting local/global values can surprise you; inspect origins. Why: debug identity, editor, and signing issues.

name: gd
description: Shows code differences before or after staging. Example: `git diff --staged`. Pitfalls: empty diff may mean changes are staged or no edits exist; try `git diff --staged` too. Why: review changes before committing mistakes.

name: gdca
description: Shows code differences before or after staging. Example: `git diff --staged`. Pitfalls: empty diff may mean changes are staged or no edits exist; try `git diff --staged` too. Why: review changes before committing mistakes.

name: gf
description: Downloads remote updates without merging into your branch. Example: `git fetch --all --prune`. Pitfalls: fetch alone does not update your working branch; merge/rebase afterward. Why: safe way to inspect remote changes first.

name: gfo
description: Downloads remote updates without merging into your branch. Example: `git fetch --all --prune`. Pitfalls: fetch alone does not update your working branch; merge/rebase afterward. Why: safe way to inspect remote changes first.

name: gfl
description: Runs Git Flow helpers for feature, release, and hotfix branches. Example: `git flow feature start login-form`. Pitfalls: Git Flow may not match your team process; confirm workflow before using. Why: adds structure for release-heavy projects.

name: gflf
description: Runs Git Flow helpers for feature, release, and hotfix branches. Example: `git flow feature start login-form`. Pitfalls: Git Flow may not match your team process; confirm workflow before using. Why: adds structure for release-heavy projects.

name: gg
description: Opens Git GUI tools to stage files and create commits visually. Example: `git gui citool`. Pitfalls: GUI may be unavailable in headless terminals; use CLI commands as fallback. Why: friendlier for beginners than raw terminal staging.

name: gga
description: Opens Git GUI tools to stage files and create commits visually. Example: `git gui citool`. Pitfalls: GUI may be unavailable in headless terminals; use CLI commands as fallback. Why: friendlier for beginners than raw terminal staging.

name: ghh
description: Opens Git documentation for commands/options. Example: `git help commit`. Pitfalls: manual pages are long; search within page for the flag you need. Why: most reliable source of command behavior.

name: glgg
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glgga
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glgp
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: gunwip
command: git log -n 1 | grep -q -c "\--wip--" && git reset HEAD~1
description: Runs multiple Git commands in sequence as one shortcut. Example: `git add --all && git commit -m "WIP"`. Pitfalls: combined steps can hide mistakes; run `git status` before/after. Why: faster repetitive workflows.

name: gignored
description: Lists files tracked by Git, often combined with filters like grep. Example: `git ls-files | grep config`. Pitfalls: grep patterns can miss matches; use `-i` for case-insensitive search. Why: fast file lookup inside repository index.

name: gfg
description: Lists files tracked by Git, often combined with filters like grep. Example: `git ls-files | grep config`. Pitfalls: grep patterns can miss matches; use `-i` for case-insensitive search. Why: fast file lookup inside repository index.

name: gm
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: gma
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: gmom
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: gmum
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: gmtl
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: gl
description: Fetches and integrates remote changes into your current branch. Example: `git pull origin main`. Pitfalls: pulling on wrong branch causes messy merges; check branch first. Why: quickly sync with team changes.

name: gpr
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gup
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gupa
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gupav
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gupv
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gupom
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: ggpull
description: Fetches and integrates remote changes into your current branch. Example: `git pull origin main`. Pitfalls: pulling on wrong branch causes messy merges; check branch first. Why: quickly sync with team changes.

name: gluc
description: Fetches and integrates remote changes into your current branch. Example: `git pull origin main`. Pitfalls: pulling on wrong branch causes messy merges; check branch first. Why: quickly sync with team changes.

name: glum
description: Fetches and integrates remote changes into your current branch. Example: `git pull origin main`. Pitfalls: pulling on wrong branch causes messy merges; check branch first. Why: quickly sync with team changes.

name: gp
description: Uploads local commits to a remote branch. Example: `git push origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: pushing wrong branch is common; confirm with `git status`. First push may need upstream via `git push -u origin <branch>`. Why: share work with teammates and CI.

name: gpd
description: Previews what a push would send without changing remote. Example: `git push --dry-run origin main`. Pitfalls: dry-run can still go stale if remote updates right after; push soon after checking. Why: safe preflight before important pushes.

name: gpf!
description: Force-pushes rewritten history to remote. Example: `git push --force-with-lease origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: can overwrite teammates' work; prefer `--force-with-lease` and coordinate on shared branches. Why: needed after local history rewrites like rebase.

name: gpf
description: Force-pushes rewritten history to remote. Example: `git push --force-with-lease origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: can overwrite teammates' work; prefer `--force-with-lease` and coordinate on shared branches. Why: needed after local history rewrites like rebase.

name: gpsup
description: Pushes and sets the branch's upstream tracking remote. Example: `git push -u origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: setting wrong upstream makes future pull/push confusing; verify remote and branch names. Why: one-time setup for simpler future pushes.

name: gpv
description: Uploads local commits to a remote branch. Example: `git push origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: pushing wrong branch is common; confirm with `git status`. First push may need upstream via `git push -u origin <branch>`. Why: share work with teammates and CI.

name: gpoat
command: git push origin --all && git push origin --tags
description: Runs multiple Git commands in sequence as one shortcut. Example: `git add --all && git commit -m "WIP"`. Pitfalls: combined steps can hide mistakes; run `git status` before/after. Why: faster repetitive workflows.

name: ggpush
description: Uploads local commits to a remote branch. Example: `git push origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: pushing wrong branch is common; confirm with `git status`. First push may need upstream via `git push -u origin <branch>`. Why: share work with teammates and CI.

name: gpu
description: Uploads local commits to a remote branch. Example: `git push origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: pushing wrong branch is common; confirm with `git status`. First push may need upstream via `git push -u origin <branch>`. Why: share work with teammates and CI.

name: grb
description: Reapplies your commits onto a new base branch. Example: `git rebase main`. Pitfalls: rebasing pushed commits rewrites history; avoid on shared/public branches. Why: clean, linear history for reviews.

name: grba
description: Reapplies your commits onto a new base branch. Example: `git rebase main`. Pitfalls: rebasing pushed commits rewrites history; avoid on shared/public branches. Why: clean, linear history for reviews.

description: Reapplies your commits onto a new base branch. Example: `git rebase main`. Pitfalls: rebasing pushed commits rewrites history; avoid on shared/public branches. Why: clean, linear history for reviews.

description: Reapplies your commits onto a new base branch. Example: `git rebase main`. Pitfalls: rebasing pushed commits rewrites history; avoid on shared/public branches. Why: clean, linear history for reviews.

name: grbd
description: Reapplies your commits onto a new base branch. Example: `git rebase main`. Pitfalls: rebasing pushed commits rewrites history; avoid on shared/public branches. Why: clean, linear history for reviews.

name: grbm
description: Reapplies your commits onto a new base branch. Example: `git rebase main`. Pitfalls: rebasing pushed commits rewrites history; avoid on shared/public branches. Why: clean, linear history for reviews.

name: grbom
description: Reapplies your commits onto a new base branch. Example: `git rebase main`. Pitfalls: rebasing pushed commits rewrites history; avoid on shared/public branches. Why: clean, linear history for reviews.

name: gr
description: Shows or edits remote repository connections. Example: `git remote -v`. Pitfalls: wrong URL/protocol causes auth failures; verify with `git remote -v`. Why: essential for fork/origin/upstream setups.

name: grv
description: Shows or edits remote repository connections. Example: `git remote -v`. Pitfalls: wrong URL/protocol causes auth failures; verify with `git remote -v`. Why: essential for fork/origin/upstream setups.

name: grset
description: Shows or edits remote repository connections. Example: `git remote -v`. Pitfalls: wrong URL/protocol causes auth failures; verify with `git remote -v`. Why: essential for fork/origin/upstream setups.

name: grup
description: Shows or edits remote repository connections. Example: `git remote -v`. Pitfalls: wrong URL/protocol causes auth failures; verify with `git remote -v`. Why: essential for fork/origin/upstream setups.

name: grh
description: Moves HEAD/index without deleting working-file edits in mixed forms. Example: `git reset -- src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: using `--hard` by accident is destructive; double-check flags. Why: fix staging/commit pointer mistakes.

name: gru
description: Moves HEAD/index without deleting working-file edits in mixed forms. Example: `git reset -- src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: using `--hard` by accident is destructive; double-check flags. Why: fix staging/commit pointer mistakes.

name: grhh
description: Hard-resets tracked files to a target commit/state. Example: `git reset --hard HEAD~1`. Pitfalls: permanently drops uncommitted changes; stash first with `git stash -u`. Why: emergency cleanup when local state is broken.

name: gpristine
description: Runs multiple Git commands in sequence as one shortcut. Example: `git add --all && git commit -m "WIP"`. Pitfalls: combined steps can hide mistakes; run `git status` before/after. Why: faster repetitive workflows.

name: groh
description: Hard-resets tracked files to a target commit/state. Example: `git reset --hard HEAD~1`. Pitfalls: permanently drops uncommitted changes; stash first with `git stash -u`. Why: emergency cleanup when local state is broken.

name: grs
description: Restores file content or unstages files safely. Example: `git restore --staged src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: restoring the wrong file discards local edits; inspect with `git diff` first. Why: modern, clearer undo flow.

name: grss
description: Restores file content or unstages files safely. Example: `git restore --staged src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: restoring the wrong file discards local edits; inspect with `git diff` first. Why: modern, clearer undo flow.

name: grst
description: Restores file content or unstages files safely. Example: `git restore --staged src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: restoring the wrong file discards local edits; inspect with `git diff` first. Why: modern, clearer undo flow.

name: grev
description: Creates a new commit that undoes an earlier commit. Example: `git revert a1b2c3d`. Pitfalls: reverting merge commits needs extra options like `-m`; check help first. Why: safe undo without rewriting shared history.

name: grm
description: Removes files from Git tracking (and optionally disk). Example: `git rm --cached .env`. Pitfalls: to keep local files, use `--cached`; add to `.gitignore` to prevent re-adding. Why: cleanly remove secrets/artifacts from history going forward.

name: grmc
description: Removes files from Git tracking (and optionally disk). Example: `git rm --cached .env`. Pitfalls: to keep local files, use `--cached`; add to `.gitignore` to prevent re-adding. Why: cleanly remove secrets/artifacts from history going forward.

name: gcount
description: Shows commit counts grouped by author names. Example: `git shortlog -sn`. Pitfalls: different emails can split one person into multiple names; use `.mailmap` if needed. Why: quick contribution summary for a repo.

name: gsh
description: Displays detailed info for a commit/tag/object. Example: `git show HEAD`. Pitfalls: large output can overwhelm; pass a file path or specific commit. Why: inspect exact changes quickly.

name: gstall
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gstaa
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gstc
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gstd
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gstl
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gstp

name: gsta
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gsts
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gst
description: Shows branch, staged, unstaged, and untracked changes. Example: `git status`. Pitfalls: skipping status leads to wrong commits; run it before commit/push. Why: best daily safety check.

name: gss
description: Shows branch, staged, unstaged, and untracked changes. Example: `git status`. Pitfalls: skipping status leads to wrong commits; run it before commit/push. Why: best daily safety check.

name: gsb
description: Shows branch, staged, unstaged, and untracked changes. Example: `git status`. Pitfalls: skipping status leads to wrong commits; run it before commit/push. Why: best daily safety check.

name: gsi
description: Initializes or updates nested repositories. Example: `git submodule update --init --recursive`. Pitfalls: forgetting `--recursive` misses nested modules and breaks builds. Why: keeps dependency repos at expected commits.

name: gsu
description: Initializes or updates nested repositories. Example: `git submodule update --init --recursive`. Pitfalls: forgetting `--recursive` misses nested modules and breaks builds. Why: keeps dependency repos at expected commits.

name: gsd
description: Bridges Git work with an SVN upstream repository. Example: `git svn rebase`. Pitfalls: mixed Git/SVN workflows can rewrite unexpectedly; keep branch linear and sync often. Why: needed for legacy SVN-integrated teams.

name: git-svn-dcommit-push
command: git svn dcommit && git push github $(git_main_branch):svntrunk
description: Bridges Git work with an SVN upstream repository. Example: `git svn rebase`. Pitfalls: mixed Git/SVN workflows can rewrite unexpectedly; keep branch linear and sync often. Why: needed for legacy SVN-integrated teams.

name: gsr
description: Bridges Git work with an SVN upstream repository. Example: `git svn rebase`. Pitfalls: mixed Git/SVN workflows can rewrite unexpectedly; keep branch linear and sync often. Why: needed for legacy SVN-integrated teams.

name: gsw
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gswc
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gswd
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gswm
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gts
description: Creates or lists release tags. Example: `git tag -a v1.2.0 -m "Release 1.2.0"`. Pitfalls: tagging wrong commit confuses releases; verify with `git show <tag>`. Why: mark versions for deploys and rollback points.

name: gtv
description: Creates or lists release tags. Example: `git tag -a v1.2.0 -m "Release 1.2.0"`. Pitfalls: tagging wrong commit confuses releases; verify with `git show <tag>`. Why: mark versions for deploys and rollback points.

name: gignore
description: Toggles low-level tracking behavior for already tracked files. Example: `git update-index --assume-unchanged .env.local`. Pitfalls: easy to forget hidden changes; undo with `--no-assume-unchanged` before sharing work. Why: useful for local machine-specific file tweaks.

name: gunignore
description: Toggles low-level tracking behavior for already tracked files. Example: `git update-index --assume-unchanged .env.local`. Pitfalls: easy to forget hidden changes; undo with `--no-assume-unchanged` before sharing work. Why: useful for local machine-specific file tweaks.

name: gwt
description: Manages multiple working directories for one repo. Example: `git worktree add ../repo-hotfix hotfix/login`. Pitfalls: same branch cannot be checked out in two worktrees; create a separate branch. Why: parallel work without constant branch switching.

name: gwta
description: Manages multiple working directories for one repo. Example: `git worktree add ../repo-hotfix hotfix/login`. Pitfalls: same branch cannot be checked out in two worktrees; create a separate branch. Why: parallel work without constant branch switching.

name: gwtls
description: Manages multiple working directories for one repo. Example: `git worktree add ../repo-hotfix hotfix/login`. Pitfalls: same branch cannot be checked out in two worktrees; create a separate branch. Why: parallel work without constant branch switching.

name: gwtmv
description: Manages multiple working directories for one repo. Example: `git worktree add ../repo-hotfix hotfix/login`. Pitfalls: same branch cannot be checked out in two worktrees; create a separate branch. Why: parallel work without constant branch switching.

name: gwtrm
description: Manages multiple working directories for one repo. Example: `git worktree add ../repo-hotfix hotfix/login`. Pitfalls: same branch cannot be checked out in two worktrees; create a separate branch. Why: parallel work without constant branch switching.

name: gbg
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gbgD
command: git branch --no-color -vv | grep ": gone\]" | awk '{print $1}' | xargs git branch -D
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gbgd
command: git branch --no-color -vv | grep ": gone\]" | awk '{print $1}' | xargs git branch -d
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gdct
description: Finds the nearest tag name for a commit (often latest version label). Example: `git describe --tags`. Pitfalls: fails or looks odd when tags are missing locally; run `git fetch --tags`. Why: handy for build/version strings.

name: gfa
description: Downloads remote updates without merging into your branch. Example: `git fetch --all --prune`. Pitfalls: fetch alone does not update your working branch; merge/rebase afterward. Why: safe way to inspect remote changes first.

name: ggsup
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gk
description: Opens GitK graphical history viewer for branches and commits. Example: `gitk --all --branches`. Pitfalls: GitK may not be installed by default; use `git log --graph` if unavailable. Why: visual branch graph helps new Git users.

name: gke
description: Opens GitK graphical history viewer for branches and commits. Example: `gitk --all --branches`. Pitfalls: GitK may not be installed by default; use `git log --graph` if unavailable. Why: visual branch graph helps new Git users.

name: glgm
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glod
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glods
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glol
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glola
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glols
description: Shows commit history and branch graph details. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: output can be noisy in big repos; limit with `--max-count=20`. Why: understand timeline and merge history quickly.

name: glp
description: Shows log output using a custom pretty format function. Example: `git log --oneline --decorate --graph`. Pitfalls: custom shell helpers may not exist everywhere; fall back to plain `git log`. Why: cleaner history view for quick reviews.

name: gms
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: gmtlvim
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: gpod
description: Uploads local commits to a remote branch. Example: `git push origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: pushing wrong branch is common; confirm with `git status`. First push may need upstream via `git push -u origin <branch>`. Why: share work with teammates and CI.

name: gpsupf
description: Force-pushes rewritten history to remote. Example: `git push --force-with-lease origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: can overwrite teammates' work; prefer `--force-with-lease` and coordinate on shared branches. Why: needed after local history rewrites like rebase.

name: grep
description: Searches text patterns in files while skipping common VCS/build folders. Example: `grep --color=auto -R "TODO" src`. Pitfalls: broad searches can be noisy; limit to specific folders like `src/`. Why: quickly find strings, errors, or TODOs.

name: grt
description: Moves your shell to the repository root directory. Example: `cd "$(git rev-parse --show-toplevel)"`. Pitfalls: outside a Git repo this can fail; check current directory first. Why: saves time when you are deep in subfolders.

name: gsps
description: Displays detailed info for a commit/tag/object. Example: `git show HEAD`. Pitfalls: large output can overwhelm; pass a file path or specific commit. Why: inspect exact changes quickly.

name: gtl
description: Lists tags matching a prefix, sorted by newest version first. Example: `git tag --sort=-v:refname -n --list "v1.*"`. Pitfalls: broad patterns can flood output; use a tighter prefix. Why: quick way to find release tags.

name: gupomi
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gwch
description: Shows commit history with patch details (older style log view). Example: `git whatchanged -p`. Pitfalls: output gets very long; limit by path or commit range. Why: deep-dive debugging of historical changes.

name: ggpnp
description: Runs multiple Git commands in sequence as one shortcut. Example: `git add --all && git commit -m "WIP"`. Pitfalls: combined steps can hide mistakes; run `git status` before/after. Why: faster repetitive workflows.

name: ggpur
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gbsn
description: Helps find the bug-introducing commit with binary search steps. Example: `git bisect start`. Pitfalls: marking commits incorrectly gives wrong results; run a reliable test each step. Why: find regressions much faster than manual checking.

name: gbso
description: Helps find the bug-introducing commit with binary search steps. Example: `git bisect start`. Pitfalls: marking commits incorrectly gives wrong results; run a reliable test each step. Why: find regressions much faster than manual checking.

name: gbm
description: Lists or manages branches. Example: `git branch -a`. Pitfalls: deleting with force can lose unmerged work; use `-d` first and verify. Why: organize feature work safely.

name: gccd
description: Runs multiple Git commands in sequence as one shortcut. Example: `git add --all && git commit -m "WIP"`. Pitfalls: combined steps can hide mistakes; run `git status` before/after. Why: faster repetitive workflows.

name: gdv
description: Shows code differences before or after staging. Example: `git diff --staged`. Pitfalls: empty diff may mean changes are staged or no edits exist; try `git diff --staged` too. Why: review changes before committing mistakes.

name: gdnolock
description: Shows code differences before or after staging. Example: `git diff --staged`. Pitfalls: empty diff may mean changes are staged or no edits exist; try `git diff --staged` too. Why: review changes before committing mistakes.

name: gprv
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gpra
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gprav
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gprom
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: gpromi
description: Pulls and rebases your local commits on top of remote changes. Example: `git pull --rebase`. Pitfalls: conflicts are normal; resolve files, `git add`, then `git rebase --continue`. Why: keeps history cleaner and linear.

name: ggl
description: Fetches and integrates remote changes into your current branch. Example: `git pull origin main`. Pitfalls: pulling on wrong branch causes messy merges; check branch first. Why: quickly sync with team changes.

name: ggf
description: Force-pushes rewritten history to remote. Example: `git push --force-with-lease origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: can overwrite teammates' work; prefer `--force-with-lease` and coordinate on shared branches. Why: needed after local history rewrites like rebase.

name: ggfl
description: Force-pushes rewritten history to remote. Example: `git push --force-with-lease origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: can overwrite teammates' work; prefer `--force-with-lease` and coordinate on shared branches. Why: needed after local history rewrites like rebase.

name: ggp
description: Uploads local commits to a remote branch. Example: `git push origin feature/login`. Pitfalls: pushing wrong branch is common; confirm with `git status`. First push may need upstream via `git push -u origin <branch>`. Why: share work with teammates and CI.

name: grhk
description: Moves HEAD/index without deleting working-file edits in mixed forms. Example: `git reset -- src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: using `--hard` by accident is destructive; double-check flags. Why: fix staging/commit pointer mistakes.

name: grhs
description: Moves HEAD/index without deleting working-file edits in mixed forms. Example: `git reset -- src/app.ts`. Pitfalls: using `--hard` by accident is destructive; double-check flags. Why: fix staging/commit pointer mistakes.

name: gstu
description: Temporarily shelves local work for later. Example: `git stash push -m "WIP login"`. Pitfalls: untracked files are skipped unless you use `-u`; stashes are easy to forget, so name them. Why: switch context without noisy WIP commits.

name: gta
description: Creates or lists release tags. Example: `git tag -a v1.2.0 -m "Release 1.2.0"`. Pitfalls: tagging wrong commit confuses releases; verify with `git show <tag>`. Why: mark versions for deploys and rollback points.

name: gcB
description: Switches branches or creates a new one. Example: `git switch feature/login`. Pitfalls: uncommitted changes can block switching; stash or commit first. Why: move between tasks quickly.

name: gcann!
description: Rewrites the most recent commit with staged updates. Example: `git commit --amend --no-edit`. Pitfalls: amending already-pushed commits rewrites shared history; create a new commit instead. Why: quickly fix last-commit mistakes before push.

name: gmc
description: Combines another branch into your current branch. Example: `git merge feature/login`. Pitfalls: merging wrong source branch causes confusion; verify branch names first. Why: integrate completed feature work.

name: grf
description: Shows local pointer history for HEAD and branches. Example: `git reflog`. Pitfalls: reflog is local and expires; recover lost commits sooner rather than later. Why: lifesaver after bad reset/rebase actions.

name: gwipe
description: Runs multiple Git commands in sequence as one shortcut. Example: `git add --all && git commit -m "WIP"`. Pitfalls: combined steps can hide mistakes; run `git status` before/after. Why: faster repetitive workflows.

name: greva
description: Creates a new commit that undoes an earlier commit. Example: `git revert a1b2c3d`. Pitfalls: reverting merge commits needs extra options like `-m`; check help first. Why: safe undo without rewriting shared history.

name: grevc
description: Creates a new commit that undoes an earlier commit. Example: `git revert a1b2c3d`. Pitfalls: reverting merge commits needs extra options like `-m`; check help first. Why: safe undo without rewriting shared history.
